quotes.topic_title: B2B growth channel progression overview
quotes.text: I do think there's actually a general path that most B2B companies take and should take.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Sets up a repeatable B2B go-to-market progression as a practical framework rather than ad hoc channel experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: B2B growth channel progression overview
quotes.text: My view is you start off with founder-led sales, the early team needs to know how to actually sell.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Emphasizes that early-stage B2B growth depends on direct selling capability before scalable channels.

quotes.topic_title: B2B growth channel progression overview
quotes.text: Then you hire your first couple of salespeople, then you start some very low cost targeted marketing efforts. So whether it's content, community, small scale events, and then PR, after all of that is when you start paid and brand effort and then SEO probably start around the same time that you start paid marketing efforts.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Provides an ordered channel sequence practitioners can follow to scale GTM from sales-led to marketing-led efforts.

quotes.topic_title: B2B growth channel progression overview
quotes.text: The reason for the progression the way I've described it is the channels get more expensive as you go farther along and they get more effective as you understand more about your customers.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Explains the underlying mental model: delay expensive channels until customer understanding makes them efficient.

quotes.topic_title: B2B growth channel progression overview
quotes.text: They hit a hundred million dollar yearly run rate in two years, which is absurd, and in the last year grew 4X during a period where most companies barely grew at all.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Gives concrete performance benchmarks that contextualize the growth playbook discussed in the episode.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Sri was VP of Ops at Opendoor, then head of growth at Instacart, and currently he's the head of growth at Ramp, which as you'll hear at the top of the episode, is the fastest growing SaaS business and the fastest growing FinTech business in history.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Establishes Sri’s cross-category growth/operator background and frames Ramp’s growth as historically exceptional.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: They hit a hundred million dollar yearly run rate in two years, which is absurd, and in the last year grew 4X during a period where most companies barely grew at all.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete growth benchmarks that set a high bar and provide a specific reference point for what “extraordinary growth” looks like.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In this episode, we zeroed in on Ramp's approach to growth.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Signals that the discussion will focus on a repeatable “approach” rather than anecdotes, useful for practitioners looking for methods.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, how they operationalize velocity, which is at the core of their team culture.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights “operationalizing velocity” as a cultural/operating-system concept that can translate into a practical methodology for teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Traditional CRMs were built for a different era with totally different speed, scale, and data demands.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A useful lens for evaluating tools: match your systems to today’s velocity, scale, and data requirements rather than legacy assumptions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It allows you to quickly build a CRM that matches your unique workflows and data structures.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Emphasizes tailoring operational systems to your actual workflows instead of forcing teams to conform to rigid software defaults.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Within minutes of connecting your email and calendar, you'll have a CRM that's already set up complete with customer profiles and automatic data enrichment.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of reducing setup friction and accelerating time-to-value through automation and pre-populated data.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If your team's work is spread out across different documents and spreadsheets and a stack of workflow tools, that's why you need Coda.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A diagnostic rule-of-thumb for when consolidation into a single system can reduce coordination overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Coda puts data in one centralized location regardless of format, eliminating roadblocks that can slow your team down.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical operating principle: centralize information to remove bottlenecks and increase execution speed.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp growth stats and scale context
quotes.text: when he released this a year ago, we were the fastest growing company to a hundred million dollars of annualized revenue at the time.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark for Ramp’s pace to $100M ARR, useful for calibrating what “hypergrowth” can look like.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp growth stats and scale context
quotes.text: I think it took two years to get to a hundred million and run rate, right?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific time-to-scale data point that frames the rest of the growth discussion.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp growth stats and scale context
quotes.text: We publicly disclosed that last year we grew Forex on top of that, very sizable based from the year prior
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Highlights continued acceleration even off a larger base—an important signal beyond the initial $100M run-rate milestone.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp growth stats and scale context
quotes.text: The company's still very lean for the amount of growth. We're under 500 people roughly today at that scale and that's definitely have a much higher revenue per employee than some of our other competitors and others in the space.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Emphasizes an efficiency lens (revenue per employee) as a practical way to evaluate scaling quality, not just growth rate.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp growth stats and scale context
quotes.text: they set ambitious goals for us on growth and I'm happy to say we've consistently beat those ambitious goals over the last 16 months or 18 months since I've joined.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Points to a repeatable operating approach: set aggressive targets and track consistent outperformance over time.

quotes.topic_title: Early Ramp growth: cap table as strategy
quotes.text: one of the things that they did is what I call cap table as a growth strategy where they did a great job of getting a large number of early stage founders and other influential operators and advisors onto the cap table at the company.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Introduces a repeatable growth framework: intentionally designing the cap table to double as a customer-acquisition and distribution engine.

quotes.topic_title: Early Ramp growth: cap table as strategy
quotes.text: And many of our initial customers were these companies that were on the cap table or the founders were on the cap table for.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Gives a concrete mechanism for how the cap-table strategy translated into early customers and word-of-mouth.

quotes.topic_title: Early Ramp growth: cap table as strategy
quotes.text: But I will say that is not as big of a channel as one might expect because companies have their own decision making frameworks for selecting a product like Ramp and the investor opinion and recommendation matters, but turns out it doesn't matter maybe as much as another customer who's actually used the product that they know or are actually experiencing the product.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway: investor intros help, but credible peer-customer usage can be a stronger driver of adoption than VC recommendations.

quotes.topic_title: Early Ramp growth: cap table as strategy
quotes.text: One example that I can think of is Eight Sleep founder, he's been very close to the Ramp team, same with the Pod founder and then a bunch of VC firms that are investors in the company are also customers of the company.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Specific examples of influential founders/investors on the cap table who also became customers, illustrating the strategy in practice.

quotes.topic_title: New acquisition vs expansion at Ramp
quotes.text: Having said all of that, what's interesting is that the vast majority of our growth back then and even to this day is via new customer acquisition.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway that even with strong natural expansion levers (spend-based revenue + new products), Ramp’s primary growth driver is still net-new logos.

quotes.topic_title: New acquisition vs expansion at Ramp
quotes.text: It's just we are adding so many more customers that the growth of our customers while strong and important part of our growth lever is not nearly as material as you might think.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Practical prioritization insight: don’t over-index on expansion assumptions if acquisition volume dominates the growth equation.

quotes.topic_title: New acquisition vs expansion at Ramp
quotes.text: And we obviously are growing our product suite as well like BillPay, Flex, et cetera, where our customers can spend more money on Ramp and get more value out of Ramp.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Illustrates a concrete expansion mechanism—broadening the product suite to increase customer spend and value—while still acknowledging acquisition is the main driver.

quotes.topic_title: New acquisition vs expansion at Ramp
quotes.text: Obviously many of our early customers have grown quite a bit and our whole strategy is to save companies time and money so they can redeploy that in other ways for their own growth or other objectives.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Clear strategic framing: position the product around measurable efficiency gains that customers can reinvest into growth.

quotes.topic_title: Channel mix and tech-driven growth advantage
quotes.text: I think the secret sauce of Ramp is not that we've found a channel that's unique and that we've over-invested or under-invested.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Contrarian point that differentiation often comes from execution (enablement) rather than discovering a novel acquisition channel.

quotes.topic_title: Channel mix and tech-driven growth advantage
quotes.text: I think what we've done differently is we've really focused on making all of those investments very much driven by technology and data.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Actionable growth methodology: apply data/tech leverage across every channel instead of optimizing channel mix alone.

quotes.topic_title: Channel mix and tech-driven growth advantage
quotes.text: we actually have a growth engineering team that's dedicated to supporting that efficiency but including adjusting third party data and using AI to automate much of their workflow, et cetera.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Concrete example of a growth-engineering function that improves sales efficiency via data enrichment and AI automation.

quotes.topic_title: Channel mix and tech-driven growth advantage
quotes.text: It's unique to Ramp where the engineers feel ownership of the quota.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Memorable operating model: align engineers to revenue outcomes (quota/pipeline) rather than only product metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Channel mix and tech-driven growth advantage
quotes.text: All of the above, helping find the right prospects, sending them the right messaging as well as prioritizing responses and drafting potential responses for the team as well.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Practical scope definition for growth engineering with sales: prospecting, messaging, prioritization, and response drafting.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp growth org structure and skunkworks
quotes.text: historically the way we've been organized is we've got channel based teams that are deploying spend in a given channel.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A clear org design principle: structure growth around channel ownership with direct accountability for spend and performance.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp growth org structure and skunkworks
quotes.text: And then we've got a product engineering team that is supporting growth and sales and helping each of these channels be more effective that's dedicated to growth.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Highlights the leverage of a dedicated growth engineering function that multiplies effectiveness across multiple channel teams.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp growth org structure and skunkworks
quotes.text: And then separate from that, we've got a small kind of what I call an innovation or skunk work type of team that works on cross-channel. Just things that don't neatly fit into a box that we think could be cool or fun to try to just do more experimentation that is cross-channel, cross-team.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A practical model for preserving experimentation by explicitly funding a cross-channel team for initiatives that don’t map cleanly to existing ownership.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp growth org structure and skunkworks
quotes.text: They've done testing of new channels that don't necessarily fit into very... And that includes new online platforms. They've done some interesting stuff on TikTok and Reddit and other places, things like that.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Concrete examples of how the skunkworks team expands the channel frontier by piloting emerging platforms before broader investment.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp growth org structure and skunkworks
quotes.text: Things that are often smaller scale and if they work we can invest more and make them larger scale later.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Codifies a staged investment approach: run small experiments first, then scale only after validation.

quotes.topic_title: Velocity culture: days mindset and execution
quotes.text: And what you see internally is what I'll say is razor-sharp focus on reducing cycle time and bias to action and how do we reduce cycle time.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A clear operational north star for moving faster: explicitly optimize for shorter cycle times and action over deliberation.

quotes.topic_title: Velocity culture: days mindset and execution
quotes.text: It's just to remind people that we don't work in years, quarters, weeks, we work in days. Each day matters and so never put out something tomorrow that you know can get done today.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A memorable mental model (“days mindset”) that makes urgency concrete and drives same-day execution.

quotes.topic_title: Velocity culture: days mindset and execution
quotes.text: So our growth team, which as I've just described, is extremely cross-functional, a lot of marketing folks and other expertise on the team, but we work a lot like a product team, we work on two-week sprints, we cross-prioritize across these teams and we work all together rather than in separate silos within the growth team.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A specific execution system for speed in growth: run like product (sprints + cross-team prioritization) instead of siloed functions.

quotes.topic_title: Velocity culture: days mindset and execution
quotes.text: And so I think one of the things that, again, not like a novel productivity tool, but something that Ramp does do is just trying to think about focus time and response times and using calendar blocking to really effectively manage your time that way.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A practical tactic for sustaining high responsiveness without constant interruption: explicitly manage focus vs response time via calendar blocks.

quotes.topic_title: Velocity culture: days mindset and execution
quotes.text: Because in many ways you ship your calendar and so thinking about how are you spending your time and then blocking your time accordingly.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A quotable reframing that turns time management into an execution artifact: your calendar is the real output of priorities.

quotes.topic_title: Work-life balance, motivation, and engagement
quotes.text: I think my biggest learnings is it's, A, some of it is like self-selection, right? You're hiring people that are excited about doing this work and this way of working, but at least I tend to find the people that I've worked with that are highly successful, ours are not the problem. It's really autonomy, flexibility, and mission alignment and the general happiness they get from their work.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A practical framework for preventing burnout among high performers: hire for intensity, then sustain it through autonomy, flexibility, and mission alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Work-life balance, motivation, and engagement
quotes.text: And so that's what I try to focus on, which is not the hours that someone's put in, but quality of the work and the impact.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A clear management principle for balancing intensity with sustainability: measure outcomes and impact rather than time spent.

quotes.topic_title: Work-life balance, motivation, and engagement
quotes.text: And I think a big part of the push to having great results and working hard is really being grateful and appreciating the team when they do push themselves and celebrating wins.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on sustaining high effort: reinforce hard pushes with gratitude and explicit celebration to keep motivation high.

quotes.topic_title: Work-life balance, motivation, and engagement
quotes.text: And it's a very one funny stat that I don't know if other companies track is we track engagement during all hands on the Zoom to see what percentage people participate. And it's usually close to a hundred percent, like people are talking, the entire company is talking on the Zoom chat because they're excited about the wins that their friends and colleagues are shipping and the things that we're talking about in the audience.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A concrete, measurable proxy for all-hands engagement (chat participation rate) plus a benchmark example (“close to a hundred percent”).

quotes.topic_title: Where to invest next: efficiency and portfolio bets
quotes.text: What I'll say on that front is, look, we, like everybody else, are always focused on driving more efficiency in our growth engine.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Emphasizes continuous efficiency improvement as a core operating principle for growth, not a one-time optimization.

quotes.topic_title: Where to invest next: efficiency and portfolio bets
quotes.text: And what you're seeing these days I think are more folks like me who actually come from an investor and analytics background to lead growth teams because growth has become more and more about a diversified portfolio of bets at a reasonable ROI and building a system that's designed around experimentation and data-oriented.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Offers a modern mental model for growth: treat it like an investment portfolio with ROI discipline and an experimentation system.

quotes.topic_title: Where to invest next: efficiency and portfolio bets
quotes.text: So the reason I say all of that is our goal is to over time, of course, make all of our channels more efficient, but also allocate more to channels that are more efficient as long as they're scalable.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Highlights a practical resource-allocation rule: shift budget toward the most efficient channels, constrained by scalability.

quotes.topic_title: Where to invest next: efficiency and portfolio bets
quotes.text: And so the more that we can push customer awareness via owned and earned media, the better for us.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Points to a strategic investment direction: prioritize owned/earned awareness to improve growth efficiency.

quotes.topic_title: PR and fundraising as growth moments
quotes.text: I think one thing that's been interesting is Ramp's ability to leverage PR as a growth machine.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Frames PR not as brand fluff but as a repeatable growth lever when executed intentionally.

quotes.topic_title: PR and fundraising as growth moments
quotes.text: what we have seen is anytime that we've been fundraising and we've been using that as an effective way of creating a market moment, it's driven actually a non-trivial amount of top funnel for us.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Highlights fundraising announcements as a measurable acquisition channel when treated as a “market moment.”

quotes.topic_title: PR and fundraising as growth moments
quotes.text: What you say it is exactly right is you have to be thoughtful about your PR moments. Everybody wants to announce things about themselves that's not necessarily interesting for the press or for an audience.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that PR only works when you optimize for audience interest, not internal milestones.

quotes.topic_title: PR and fundraising as growth moments
quotes.text: So our fundraising announcements usually also have some additional color on something unique about the business that we share to provide more value to readers.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Gives a concrete tactic: pair announcements with unique business insights to increase newsworthiness and reader value.

quotes.topic_title: PR and fundraising as growth moments
quotes.text: But as I mentioned, the vast majority of the world is not startups and the majority of Ramp's customers are no longer tech and startups.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Counterbalances the “tech echo chamber” by emphasizing channel choice should match where your real customers are.

quotes.topic_title: Building growth engines: culture over structure
quotes.text: But I think design of the team, people often... I think it's a red herring about team structure and team design and what's the right one, et cetera. I think most of that is irrelevant. What actually matters is culture and rituals and cadences rather than the team itself.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Contrarian take that de-emphasizes org design and emphasizes operating culture (rituals/cadence) as the real growth lever.

quotes.topic_title: Building growth engines: culture over structure
quotes.text: And so what a great growth engine and a great growth team is one that where you set the culture, set very simple north star metrics, usually one, at most two.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to focus the organization by choosing an extremely small set of north-star metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Building growth engines: culture over structure
quotes.text: And you've created a culture of defining hypotheses that are data driven and a culture where that can be executed quickly and have an MVP mentality for product and non-product projects where people can fail and learn quickly and iterate quickly.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A repeatable methodology for growth: data-driven hypotheses + fast execution + MVPs + rapid learning loops.

quotes.topic_title: Building growth engines: culture over structure
quotes.text: It's like can you build a set of people that can generate new ideas and evaluate them effectively and move quickly is really what you're trying to design for.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Defines the core capability of a growth engine as idea generation, evaluation, and speed—not specific roles or functions.

quotes.topic_title: North star metrics and translation layers (Instacart)
quotes.text: One of the things that we did is the actual local team has their own metric that they can directly influence. You want to actually hold people accountable for things that they can influence. And then we created via the finance and data team, a translation layer for every team's metric into MAO.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A practical operating model: let teams optimize controllable local metrics, but translate everything back to a single north star for alignment.

quotes.topic_title: North star metrics and translation layers (Instacart)
quotes.text: And the other benefit of doing something like that is that it also helps you cross-prioritize much easier. Should we add more engineering to this team? Should we add more budget to that team? It's like, okay, well what's the MAO map? Where is there a more MAO per dollar or per engineer being built? And it just really helped us unify and move together.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Shows how a translation layer enables resource allocation decisions using a common unit (north-star impact per dollar/engineer).

quotes.topic_title: North star metrics and translation layers (Instacart)
quotes.text: The only thing you can be certain of is that you're not going to accomplish exactly the plan.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A counterintuitive planning mindset that encourages using metric models as guides rather than precision instruments.

quotes.topic_title: North star metrics and translation layers (Instacart)
quotes.text: One is setting a culture of we know this isn't perfect, this is like 70/30, 80/20, it's to guide. So we wouldn't use the translation factor to make a marginal decision if something is five or 10% off.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on how to use imperfect metric translations responsibly—avoid over-optimizing on small deltas.

quotes.topic_title: North star metrics and translation layers (Instacart)
quotes.text: And the other thing that we just had as cadence is we would actually update all of the translations every six months for the new planning cycle based on new information that we knew on how moving X impacts MAO.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A concrete cadence for keeping translation factors accurate enough to be useful in planning and prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp north star example and activation insights
quotes.text: I think this actually becomes much more important as companies get bigger because there's more teams to prioritize and more resources to cross-allocate. And having a common currency makes that a lot easier.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A clear mental model for why north star metrics matter more with scale: they enable prioritization and resource allocation across many teams.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp north star example and activation insights
quotes.text: in the recent past it was for the growth team, the north star was dollars of SQL pipeline. So anything anybody did, we would try to estimate the impact into what would be the dollars of sales qualified lead pipeline generated for Ramp.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A concrete example of a growth north star and how to translate disparate work into a single business-impact metric.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp north star example and activation insights
quotes.text: Finding the right success metric, there usually should be two. There should be one on volume and another one on efficiency.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for metric design: pair a scale metric with an efficiency metric to avoid one-sided optimization.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp north star example and activation insights
quotes.text: And it's also clear, if they're working on some minutiae, how that can impact and actually move the main metric. So it's usually you have to find something that's somewhere in between, not too far, too lag, towards revenue and value creation, but also not something that's actually translatable to the efforts of various teams.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for choosing metrics that balance business value with day-to-day team controllability.

quotes.topic_title: Ramp north star example and activation insights
quotes.text: And at Ramp, for our activation, I mean it's very specific to Ramp, but we've got four events that the customer needs to do in the first 30 days. And if they do that, they have a high likelihood of being activated and successful. So our activation team focuses on that.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: An “escape-velocity” activation approach: define a small set of early actions within a time window that predicts long-term success.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Wherever you work, running experiments is increasingly essential, but there are no commercial tools that integrate with a modern growth team stack.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical gap teams face: experimentation is mandatory, but tooling often doesn’t fit modern stacks, creating operational drag.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This leads to waste of time building internal tools or trying to run your own experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable warning about the hidden cost of poor experimentation infrastructure—either DIY tool-building or misusing ill-suited tools.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved most about working there was our experimentation platform where I was able to slice and dice data by device types, country, user stage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of an effective experimentation capability: fast segmentation across key dimensions to diagnose impact.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: EPO lets you go beyond basic clickthrough metrics and instead use your north star metrics like activation, retention, subscription and payments.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Memorable measurement framework: optimize experiments against north-star outcomes rather than shallow proxy metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Efficiency metrics: payback period vs CAC (start)
quotes.text: There's a fundamental flaw to it which obviously is that you're focusing on cost and not the value derived.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Challenges the common CAC obsession by reframing acquisition efficiency around value creation, not just spend.

quotes.topic_title: Efficiency metrics: payback period vs CAC (start)
quotes.text: And so when you focus on CAC and reducing CAC, what tends to happen is you actually might be doing something very damaging where you're succeeding in reducing CAC, but you're actually bringing in customers that are less valuable because those are the ones that you're able to attract with a lower CAC.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Warns that optimizing for lower CAC can backfire by shifting the customer mix toward lower-value users.

quotes.topic_title: Efficiency metrics: payback period vs CAC (start)
quotes.text: And so reframing it away from CAC towards LTV is helpful and that's better.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Provides a practical metric shift practitioners can apply: prioritize lifetime value over acquisition cost alone.

quotes.topic_title: Efficiency metrics: payback period vs CAC (start)
quotes.text: So thinking about for better customers that are bigger, we want to spend more.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Offers a counterintuitive budgeting principle: higher spend can be rational if it buys higher-quality customers.

quotes.topic_title: Efficiency metrics: payback period vs CAC (start)
quotes.text: I think the challenge with LTV to CAC especially for a lot of, even Ramp, it's only four years old, is it's really hard to predict LTV.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Highlights a key limitation of LTV:CAC for newer companies—LTV uncertainty—motivating alternative ROI lenses like payback period.
